learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate broad knowledge of the relevant areas of law.
Effectively interview clients and take instructions.
Practise in an ethical manner with due sensitivity to clients' individual circumstances.
Provide written legal advice, i.e. research, analyse and write about legal issues relevant to clients in the appropriate format.
Manage client files consistent with organisational practices.
Undertake effective self-reflection on the practice of law.
Research the law relevant to the client's situation.
Write letters and work with lawyers to respond to the client’s legal and non-legal (where possible/appropriate) problems.
Successfully use a variety of communication technologies to effectively interview clients, including telephone and video link-up.
Demonstrate knowledge of the multiple needs of clients across a range of disciplines where relevant (e.g. social work, medicine, psychology, finance).
Effectively communicate legal concepts to professionals and students of other disciplines and share knowledge to work towards a common outcome.
Understand the concept of cultural competence and identify situations when legal practice is culturally unsafe for Indigenous peoples.
Where relevant, work under the direction of an Indigenous lawyer.

assessments.assessment_title: Clinical days AND induction and debrief sessions
assessments.task_description:
Attendance is an inherent requirement of this course. Students are expected to attend (in person) all clinical sessions and any induction and debriefing workshops / sessions required by supervising organisations. Students are informed of the dates and times of their particular clinic by clinical supervisors.

The compulsory pre-placement 2hr induction session will be held on Monday 28 July 2025 after 4pm (exact time and room TBC, you will be advised on Blackboard).

The compulsory 1.5hr debrief session will be held in week 13, after 4pm on Monday 27 October 2025 (exact time and room TBC, you will be advised on Blackboard).

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct .
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
In Week 2, students must submit a personalised learning plan using a template document supplied by the Course Coordinator (details supplied on Blackboard subject site). The learning plan asks students to:

a) Answer some questions about their study of law; b) Undertake a short analysis of their personal strengths and challenges that they consider they bring to the course; c) Articulate their personal learning goals for the course. 

The purpose of this assessment is for students, their clinical supervisor and the Course Coordinator to obtain a shared understanding of students' goals for the course. 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct Policy.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments must be submitted electronically via the submission link on the course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to write two reflections on their clinic experience: one mid-semester (due at the end of week 6), and one at the end of semester (due at the end of week 13). 

For the first reflective journal, students must write 500 words reflecting on their assumptions about clinical placement. In order to pass you must reflect on one or more discrete experiences whilst on placement; and may also reflect on the nature of the client group or legal problems they are dealing with etc. 

The purpose of the reflection is professional and personal development. It is not an academic task, as much as an opportunity to consolidate your experiences and your learning, and to think about what this means for you as an emerging practitioner. 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct Policy.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments must be submitted electronically via the submission link on the course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
For the final reflective journal, students must engage in a similar exercise to the initial reflection, but must write 800 words. In order to pass you must reflect on your actual experiences during clinic. In this reflection, students should take the time to also specifically reflect on how they have integrated the theory and skills they have learnt during their formal university studies with the practice they are engaging in whilst on placement. Students may also consider reflecting on the practice of law for vulnerable groups in society. 

For the testimonial, students must submit either a written (150 words) or video (1-2 minutes) testimonial outlining:

(1) what you learned from your clinical experience; and

(2) whether you would recommend clinic to other students, and why/why not.

This can be done either as an individual or as a group.

Our intention is to publish these testimonials to provide information to students who may be considering taking LAWS5180. If you submit a written testimonial, we can de-identify it before publication at your request. If we would like to publish your video, we will seek your permission first.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct Policy.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Culturally Safe Criminal Law Practice

Culturally Safe Criminal Law Practice: This clinic operates every Tuesday at YFS Ltd (Youth and Family Services) on Kingston Road, Slacks Creek. Students engage with guest speakers, and undertake other activities to learn more about the injustices facing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples interacting with the justice system (particularly youth justice) and the work of Indigenous legal practitioners and communities. They also undertake legal tasks (writing submissions, preparing briefs etc) relating to youth justice and criminal law, with a focus on working with Indigenous clients under the supervision of an Indigenous lawyer.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11, L12, L13
learning_activities.topic_description: Culturally Safe Criminal Law Practice Culturally Safe Criminal Law Practice: This clinic operates every Tuesday at YFS Ltd (Youth and Family Services) on Kingston Road, Slacks Creek. They also undertake legal tasks (writing submissions, preparing briefs etc) relating to youth justice and criminal law, with a focus on working with Indigenous clients under the supervision of an Indigenous lawyer.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Prison Law and Deaths in Custody Clinic

These clinic operates every Tuesday at the Prisoners' Legal Service. Students undertake case work and law reform/policy work relating to prison law, in particular assisting clients with applications for parole; and undertake action research on deaths in custody in Australia.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11, L12, L13
learning_activities.topic_title: Prison Law and Deaths in Custody Clinic
learning_activities.topic_description: Prison Law and Deaths in Custody Clinic These clinic operates every Tuesday at the Prisoners' Legal Service. Students undertake case work and law reform/policy work relating to prison law, in particular assisting clients with applications for parole; and undertake action research on deaths in custody in Australia.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Environmental Law Clinic

This clinic operates every Tuesday at the Environmental Defenders Office. Students undertake casework, environmental law reform and policy work. Preference is given to students who have completed courses in environmental and/or planning law and who have a demonstrated commitment to environmental issues.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11, L12, L13

Students undertake casework, environmental law reform and policy work. Preference is given to students who have completed courses in environmental and/or planning law and who have a demonstrated commitment to environmental issues.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Homelessness Law Clinic

This clinic operates every Tuesday. Students undertake client work at Law Right and attend outreach legal clinics at community services to interview clients and undertake legal casework.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11, L12, L13
learning_activities.topic_description: Homelessness Law Clinic This clinic operates every Tuesday. Students undertake client work at Law Right and attend outreach legal clinics at community services to interview clients and undertake legal casework.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Health Advocacy (Mater) Legal Clinic

Law students will be placed at the Mater Young Adult Health Centre, South Brisbane either every Wednesday. Law students in HALC work in a multidisciplinary team alongside social work and medical/nursing law students, and hospital medical staff to provide legal advice and assistance to patients. Areas of law include guardianship and administration, mental health, estate planning and anti-discrimination.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11, L12, L13
learning_activities.topic_description: Health Advocacy (Mater) Legal Clinic Law students will be placed at the Mater Young Adult Health Centre, South Brisbane either every Wednesday. Areas of law include guardianship and administration, mental health, estate planning and anti-discrimination.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Tenancy Law Clinic

This clinic operates every Wednesday from Tenants Queensland premises in Spring Hill. Students will undertake legal casework, information and advice on areas relating to residential tenancy law.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11, L12, L13
learning_activities.topic_description: Tenancy Law Clinic This clinic operates every Wednesday from Tenants Queensland premises in Spring Hill. Students will undertake legal casework, information and advice on areas relating to residential tenancy law.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Refugee and Immigration Law Clinic

This clinic operates every Thursday at RAILS (the Refugee and Immigration Legal Service). Students work with lawyers undertaking immigration related casework including for people on onshore protection visas, and people on temporary visas who have experienced family violence. Preference will be given to students who have studied Immigration & Refugee Law, or who have a demonstrated interest in this area.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11, L12, L13
learning_activities.topic_description: Refugee and Immigration Law Clinic This clinic operates every Thursday at RAILS (the Refugee and Immigration Legal Service). Students work with lawyers undertaking immigration related casework including for people on onshore protection visas, and people on temporary visas who have experienced family violence. Preference will be given to students who have studied Immigration & Refugee Law, or who have a demonstrated interest in this area.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Consumer Law Advice Clinic (CLAC)

The CLAC runs out of Caxton Legal Centre on a Friday. Students undertake advice and case work with clients experiencing consumer credit and debt issues.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11, L12, L13

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Generalist Legal Tasks Clinic

The Generalist Legal Tasks Clinic runs out of YFS Legal on a Thursday. Students undertake a variety of discrete legal tasks (e.g. letters and application forms) under supervision of a lawyer. Students have direct phone and face-to-face contact with clients. They may also be asked to help with legal research and preparing legal advice. A Blue Card is required for this clinic.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11, L12, L13
learning_activities.topic_description: Generalist Legal Tasks Clinic The Generalist Legal Tasks Clinic runs out of YFS Legal on a Thursday . Students undertake a variety of discrete legal tasks (e.g. letters and application forms) under supervision of a lawyer. Students have direct phone and face-to-face contact with clients. They may also be asked to help with legal research and preparing legal advice. A Blue Card is required for this clinic.

learning_activities.topic:
Induction session - compulsory

The compulsory pre-placement 2hr induction session will be held on Monday 28 July 2025 at 4pm - 6pm (room TBC). Attendance is in-person only. If you are unwell on 28 July, you must obtain a medical certificate and contact the Course Coordinator to discuss options.

All students going on placement must also complete Modules 1 and 2 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Core Cultural Learning course (available via Blackboard).

Learning outcomes: L06, L12
